title: 108_hr4431
content: The Act may be cited as the "One Church, One Child Act of 2004". The Congress finds a shortage of foster and adoptive parents, with a decrease in foster parents despite an increase in children in foster care. There is a significant need for post-adoption services due to the rise in adoptions from foster care. One Church, One Child is a national foster care and adoption ministry founded in 1980 in Chicago, Illinois. It aims to provide services for at-risk children and support adoptive, foster, and kinship families. Despite its success in placing over 140,000 children in adoptive families, the organization receives limited federal funding. One Church, One Child has successfully placed over 140,000 children in adoptive families nationwide. Despite its success, programs based on this concept have limited federal funding. A federally-funded grant program to support similar programs will benefit abused and neglected children by increasing the pool of qualified adoptive and foster parents. SEC. 479B. ONE CHURCH, ONE CHILD GRANTS. Part E of title IV of the Social Security Act is amended to include a federally-funded grant program to support programs like One Church, One Child, benefiting abused and neglected children by increasing the pool of adoptive and foster parents. The Secretary will provide competitive grants to eligible entities to establish or expand programs that recruit and train foster and adoptive parents through public, private, and faith-based organizations. Eligible entities include state or local governments, public agencies, nonprofit organizations, and private entities. Application submission is required as per the Secretary's guidelines. The Secretary will provide competitive grants to eligible entities, including state or local governments, public agencies, nonprofit organizations, and private entities, to establish or expand programs that recruit and train foster and adoptive parents. Applicants must submit an application containing project descriptions and coordination efforts as required by the Secretary. The Secretary will provide grants to entities to establish programs for recruiting and training foster and adoptive parents. Entities must describe services, coordinate with state and local agencies, and maintain records for oversight. The term 'State' refers to all 50 states and the District of Columbia. The Secretary will provide grants to entities to establish programs for recruiting and training foster and adoptive parents. Entities must maintain records, submit reports, and cooperate with reviews and audits as necessary for oversight. The term 'State' refers to all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and other territories. Authorization of appropriations is limited to $20,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2005 to 2009. Grant funds must be expended within three years, with unused funds to be remitted to the Secretary. Entities receiving grants under this section must remit any unexpended funds to the Secretary, along with earnings. The Secretary will redistribute these funds to eligible entities in need. Religious organizations are considered equally for grants, as long as they comply with the Establishment Clause. Religious organizations receiving grants under this section must comply with the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment. They cannot be discriminated against based on their religious character. The Federal Government or a State/local government cannot interfere with a religious organization's internal governance or require the removal of religious symbols to receive funding. Funds provided to religious organizations cannot be used for sectarian worship, instruction, or proselytization. Religious organizations receiving funds under this section must adhere to limitations on the use of funds, including not using the funds for sectarian worship, instruction, or proselytization. They are also required to maintain fiscal accountability by following generally accepted accounting principles and keeping the funds separate from other organization funds. SEC. 479C. National Clearinghouse for Adoption Promotion and Foster Parent Recruitment Programs; Annual Report to Congress. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to assist in coordinating activities for foster parent and adoptive parent recruitment, providing technical assistance and training, and disseminating best practices. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to assist in coordinating activities for foster parent and adoptive parent recruitment, providing technical assistance, training, and disseminating best practices. This includes collecting information on program effectiveness and assisting in evaluating programs. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to assist in coordinating activities for foster parent and adoptive parent recruitment, providing technical assistance, training, and disseminating best practices. This organization will collect data on program effectiveness and help evaluate programs. The nationally recognized, nonprofit adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment organization selected by the Secretary must have experience in providing consultation and training to faith-based and community organizations interested in adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to assist in coordinating activities for foster parent and adoptive parent recruitment, providing technical assistance, training, and disseminating best practices. The selected organization must have experience in working with faith-based and community organizations to recruit and train prospective foster and adoptive parents, as well as in establishing programs based on the One Church, One Child model. Up to $1,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2005 to 2009 for this purpose. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to assist in coordinating activities for foster parent and adoptive parent recruitment, providing technical assistance, training, and disseminating best practices. Up to $1,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2005 to 2009 for this purpose. Annual reports detailing the number of entities receiving grants, foster parents and adoptive families recruited, children placed, and program evaluation information will be submitted to Congress.
